chunks.original_text: ○李氏曰：无为则无事，有为则有事，执者失，为者败，有为之戒也。 ○林氏曰：天下神器，岂人力所可得。 道盛德至，天下归之。 若萌取天下之心而强为善，以求有得，次不可得矣。 盖言凡天下之事，不可以有心求。 为者必败，执者必失，是皆有心之累也。 凡物或行或随，或呴或吹，或强或羸，或载或隳。 是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。 何氏曰：物损於彼者盈於此，成於此者亏於彼，损盈成亏，往来相接，《列子》所谓螳螂捕蝉，不知黄雀在后，亦是此意。 故物或行而前，已有随其后者，或呴而暖，已有吹之寒者，或强而胜，已有羸而弱之者，或载而成，已有车而坏之者，如相守然，故曰影之守人也，物之守物也，况天下大於物，而可以有心有为有执哉。 甚者过当，道以弱为表，以虚为实，不为已甚，故去甚奢者浮靡也。 道以本为精，以物为粗，奢则不逊，故去奢泰者骄肆也。 道以深为根，以约为纪，而不以天下为泰，故去泰。 此三者皆有作为之侈心，去此三者，圣人之心虚矣，不以天下动其心矣。 ○李氏曰：强赢载隳，互相倚伏，如影随形，才有成便有败，是以圣人去贪甚，去奢侈，去骄泰，深戒后世。 ○苏氏曰：或行於前，或随於后，或呴而暖，或吹而寒，或强而益，或羸而损，或载而成，或隳而毁，皆物之自然，势之不可免者也。 ○吴氏曰：此承上文执者失之一句而言，守天下之道，有天下者，岂能保天下之长为我有而不亡也哉，盖得失存亡之相禅，如行随呴吹强羸载隳，八者相反而相因，圣人知其势之必至於此也，而处之有其道焉。 凡过盛则必衰，惟不使过盛，则可以不衰也也，能不过盛甚奢泰三者，盛之极则可以保天下矣。 道德真经集义卷之四竟 道德真经集义卷之五
chunks.translated_text:
The **Li Family** says:
*"To act is to have affairs; not to act is to have no affairs. Those who grasp lose; those who act fail—this is the warning against action."*

The **Lin Family** says:
*"The divine vessel of the world—
how can it be attained by human strength?
When the Dao flourishes and virtue reaches its peak,
the world submits to it.
If one harbors the intention to seize the world and forcefully do good,
seeking to gain something,
then the unattainable becomes even more so.
For all things under heaven,
one must not seek them with intention.
Those who act will fail;
those who grasp will lose—
these are the burdens of intention.
All things either move forward or follow,
either warm with breath or chill with wind,
either prevail with strength or falter with weakness,
either succeed with elevation or collapse with ruin.
Thus, the Sage avoids excess,
avoids extravagance,
avoids extravagance—
this is the **He Family**’s teaching:
*What is lost to one is gained by another;
what is completed here is deficient there.
Loss and gain, completion and deficiency—
they cycle endlessly, as in the *Liezi*’s parable:
the praying mantis seizes the cicada,
unaware of the sparrow behind.
Thus, when one moves forward, another follows;
when one breathes warmth, another blows cold;
when one prevails with strength, another weakens it;
when one succeeds with elevation, another ruins it—
they guard each other like shadows to form,
like things guarding things.
How much more so the world, greater than all things,
can one have intention, action, or grasping?
Excess is overreaching—
the Dao takes weakness as its standard,
emptiness as its substance,
and avoids overreaching—
thus, to remove excess is to eliminate frivolous waste.
The Dao takes origin as its refinement,
things as its coarseness—
extravagance leads to insolence,
thus, to remove extravagance is to eliminate arrogant excess.
The Dao takes depth as its root,
simplicity as its measure,
and does not consider the world as extravagant—
thus, to remove extravagance is to avoid arrogance.
These three are all the extravagant hearts of action;
removing these three,
the Sage’s heart is empty—
the world cannot disturb it."*

The **Li Family** says:
*"Strength and weakness, elevation and ruin—
they mutually rely and overturn each other,
like shadows following form.
Where there is success, there is also failure—
thus, the Sage avoids greed for excess,
avoids extravagance,
avoids arrogance and extravagance,
and deeply warns future generations."*

The **Su Family** says:
*"Some move forward, some follow behind;
some breathe warmth, some blow cold;
some strengthen and benefit, some weaken and diminish;
some succeed with elevation, some ruin with collapse—
these are the natural ways of things,
inevitable forces that cannot be avoided."*

The **Wu Family** says:
*"This follows the earlier warning: *‘Those who grasp lose.’*
The Way of governing the world—
those who hold the world,
how can they long preserve it as their own without losing it?
The cycles of gain and loss, survival and ruin,
are like moving forward and following,
breathing warmth and blowing cold,
strength and weakness,
elevation and ruin—
these eight opposites interdependently arise.
The Sage knows these forces must reach this point,
and thus has a Way to respond.
All that is overabundant must decline—
only by preventing overabundance
can one avoid decline.
If one does not exceed in greed, extravagance, or arrogance,
then at the peak of abundance,
one can preserve the world.
*The Collected Commentaries on the Dao De Jing*, Volume Four concludes.
Volume Five begins."*

chunks.original_text: 盱江危大有集 第三十章 以道佐人主者，不以兵强天下。 其事好还。 吕氏曰：有道之士辅佐其君，莫不务以德为本，三军五兵，德之末也，君使臣以礼，臣事君以忠，无为而民自化，庶俗熙熙，知帝力之何有，以从事於甲兵，岂道也哉。 兵者凶象，战者危事，非君子之器，不得已而用之，有胜则有败，有利则有害，岂可以强侵弱，暴凌善，兽穷则搏，物极则反，此必然也。 ○倪氏曰：不曰人主，而曰以道佐人主者，盖言人主虽有用兵之意，苟大臣不从，更之未必用也。 ○林氏曰：佐人主而以强兵为心，则非知道矣。 兵，凶器也，我以害人，则人将以害我，故曰其事好还。 ○王氏曰：以道佐人主，尚不以兵强天下，况人主躬於道者乎。 师之所处，荆棘生焉。 大军之后，必有凶年。 吕氏曰：师旅所过之地，古今争战之场，鲜有所济，田荒室露，荆棘森然，可不畏乎。 大军一过，上违天时，下夺民力，和气不应於上，杀气横流於下，民之与物，悉被戕贼，六气不均，雨旸失时，疵疠灾害，兵兴荒歉，必至凶年，理之常也。 ○苏氏曰：兵兴所在，民事废，田不修。 用兵之后，杀气腾，年谷伤。 ○政和注：下夺民力，故荆棘生，上违天时，故有凶年。 ○林氏曰：用师之地，农不得耕，荆棘生焉，用兵之后，伤天地之和气，则必有凶年之首。 故善者果而已，不敢以取强。 果而勿矜，果而勿伐，果而勿骄，果而不得已，果而勿强。 吕氏曰：强兵战胜，禁暴御乱之术，亦不可废，犹水火焉，善用之则为福，不善用之则为祸，善用兵者，果决而已，不敢以取强也。 德所不能化，政所不能及，不得已而后起，迫而后动，动罔不利，非恃强而有取也。 此善胜之道也明矣。 果而不矜其能，自矜则不长，果而勿伐其善，自伐则无功。 果而勿骄其势，自骄则不足。 侵伐之事，救而可也，非用果以为强也。 ○何氏曰：善不在用兵而善用，其所谓果者，盖见善明，用心刚之谓果。 凡果者次於为善，而不果决以为兵也，传所谓心竞力争之辨，故曰果而不敢以取强。 又曰：果而勿强也。 夫勿矜能，勿伐功，勿骄气，不得已而后应者，皆善心之所发，则果断以行之，是不以心竞也。 惟至强兵一事，则果断以去之，是不以力争也。 ○董氏曰：兵固有道者不取，然天生五材亦不可去，譬水火焉，在乎善用，惟以止暴济难，则果次於理而已。 凡理义之在我，则所守者不屈矣。 《春秋传》曰：杀敌为果，言杀敌者令不相侵而已，何敢取强於天下哉。 果以理胜，强以力胜，惟果则隐然有必克之势，初非恃力好战，故临事而惧，好谋而成，不得已而后应之，勿强而已。 物壮则老，是谓不道，不道早已。 林氏曰：强者不能终强，矜者不能终矜，譬犹万物之既壮，则老必至矣，不知此理，而欲以取强於天下，皆不道者也。 既知此为不道，则当急去之，故曰早已。 已者已而勿为也。 ○苏氏曰：壮之又老，物无不然，惟有道者成而若缺，盈而若冲，未尝壮，未尝老，未尝死，以兵强天下，壮亦甚矣，而能无老乎。 ○何氏曰：圣人何以自视退怯，不忍求胜於天下哉，则有见夫日中则反，月盈则亏，物壮则老将至，岂道之常哉，如知其非常道，则早复於道，早去其非道，亡国之事故不一，而佳兵者必亡。
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Thirty: Those Who Assist the Sovereign with the Dao Do Not Use Military Might to Subdue the World**

Their affairs tend to return.

**Master Lü** says:
Those of the Dao who assist their sovereign must first establish virtue as their foundation. Armies and weapons are but the final means. The sovereign governs ministers with propriety, and ministers serve the sovereign with loyalty. If the ruler acts without artifice, the people transform themselves spontaneously. The common folk flourish in harmony, unaware of imperial might, yet they engage in warfare—how can this be the Dao?

War is an omen of calamity, and battle is a perilous affair. It is not the instrument of the virtuous. Used only when unavoidable, victory brings defeat, and gain brings harm. How can one justly subdue the weak or violently oppress the good? When beasts are cornered, they strike back; when things reach their extreme, they reverse. This is inevitable.

**Master Ni** says:
It does not say *"the sovereign"* but *"those who assist the sovereign with the Dao,"* meaning that even if the sovereign harbors intentions of war, if the great ministers do not comply, he may not necessarily act upon them.

**Master Lin** says:
To assist the sovereign while prioritizing military strength is not to know the Dao. War is a cruel instrument—if I harm others, others will harm me in return. Thus, it is said that such affairs tend to return.

**Master Wang** says:
Those who assist the sovereign with the Dao still refrain from using military might to subdue the world—how much more so should the sovereign himself, who embodies the Dao?

Where the teacher treads, brambles grow.
After great armies pass, there will surely be years of famine.

**Master Lü** says:
Where armies have marched, both ancient and modern battlefields, few reap lasting benefit. Fields lie fallow, homes stand empty, and brambles thrive—how can one not fear this?

When great armies march, they disrupt the natural order above and drain the people’s strength below. Harmonious *qi* fails to ascend, and killing *qi* floods below. Both people and things suffer violence. The six *qi* become unbalanced, and rain and sun lose their proper timing. Plagues and disasters follow, and famine ensues after war—this is the natural course.

**Master Su** says:
Where war is waged, civil affairs falter, and fields lie untended. After battle, killing *qi* surges, and crops wither.

**Political Harmony Annotation**:
The people’s strength is drained below, hence brambles grow. The natural order is disrupted above, hence years of famine follow.

**Master Lin** says:
In lands where armies are deployed, farmers cannot till the soil, and brambles arise. After war, the harmony of Heaven and Earth is wounded, and years of famine inevitably follow. Thus, the virtuous act decisively but do not seek strength. Act decisively without arrogance, without boasting, without pride—act only when unavoidable, and do not seek strength.

**Master Lü** says:
Though military strength and victory in battle are methods to suppress violence and quell disorder, they must not be discarded—like water and fire, their proper use brings blessing, but misuse brings ruin. Those who skillfully wield arms act decisively but do not seek strength. What virtue cannot transform and what governance cannot reach must be addressed only when unavoidable, pressed only when necessary. When they act, they do so without fail, not relying on strength to take what is not theirs. This is the clear path of virtuous victory.

Act decisively without boasting of your ability—for boasting leads to decline.
Act decisively without praising your virtue—for praise undermines true merit.
Act decisively without growing proud of your power—for pride leads to insufficiency.

Matters of aggression may be addressed, but not to seek strength.

**Master He** says:
Virtue lies not in waging war but in wielding it well. By *"decisive"* (*guǒ*), he means clarity of vision and firm resolve. Decisiveness is secondary to doing good, not to wielding arms for conquest. As the *Classic* says: *"The contest is of heart and strength."* Thus, one acts decisively but does not seek strength. Again, it says: *"Act decisively but do not seek strength."*

To not boast of ability, not to praise one’s deeds, not to grow arrogant—these are the expressions of a virtuous heart. Thus, one acts with decisive resolve, not competing in heart. Only in the matter of extreme military strength does one act decisively to reject it, not competing in force.

**Master Dong** says:
Though the Dao rejects war, Heaven endows the five elements, which cannot be discarded—like water and fire, their proper use is essential. Only when used to suppress violence and aid the distressed does decisiveness follow principle. Whatever principles and righteousness belong to us, we uphold them without bending.

The *Spring and Autumn Annals* says: *"Decisive action means killing enemies to prevent mutual aggression—how dare one seek strength over the world?"*

Decisive action wins through principle; strength wins through force. Decisiveness carries an inherent certainty of victory, yet it does not rely on force or delight in war. Thus, when facing matters, one fears, plans carefully, and acts only when unavoidable—simply avoiding strength.

When things reach their peak, they decline—this is called *not the Dao*. *Not the Dao* must be abandoned early.

**Master Lin** says:
The strong cannot remain strong, the arrogant cannot remain arrogant. Just as all things, once at their peak, must decline—those who do not understand this principle yet seek to dominate the world are acting against the Dao. Knowing this, they must swiftly abandon it. *"Early abandonment"* means to cease and not persist.

**Master Su** says:
Things grow strong, then decline—none escape this. Only those of the Dao, though complete, appear deficient; though full, appear empty. They never grow strong, never decline, never die. To use military might to subdue the world is extreme strength—how can it avoid decline?

**Master He** says:
Why does the Sage retreat in humility, unwilling to seek victory over the world? Because He sees that when the sun reaches its zenith, it declines; when the moon is full, it wanes; when things reach their peak, decline follows. Is this not the natural course of the Dao? If one knows this is not the Dao, then one must swiftly return to it, swiftly abandon what is not the Dao. The causes of ruined states are many, but those who delight in arms are doomed to fall.

chunks.original_text: 以道相人国家，可不以佳兵为戒，而善用其果哉。 ○董氏曰：物壮极则老，兵强极则败，故兵之恃强，则不可全其善胜，物之用壮，适所以速其衰老，皆非合道，宜早知止。 第三十一章 夫佳兵者，不祥之器，物或恶之，故有道者不处也。 林氏曰：佳兵，喜用兵也，以用兵为佳，此不祥之人也，以不祥之人行不祥之事，故曰不祥之器，此天下之所恶，故有道者不为也。 ○李氏曰：不以兵强天下，故次之以兵者不祥之器，圣人於此深戒万世之下有国之君，以无为清净治化，自然家国安宁，虽有甲兵，无所陈之，永无争夺之患也。 ○吕氏曰：兵非太平致治之具，伐暴可也，既不得已而用之，岂免多阴谋乎，夫好戈甲以为服玩者，是尚不善之用也，所谓佳其凶器以幸天下，非特人恶，物亦惮之。 ○《续资治通鉴》宋太宗谓近臣曰：朕读《老子》至佳兵者不祥之器，圣人不得已而用之，未尝不三复以为规戒。 君子居则贵左，用兵则贵右。 兵者不祥之器，非君子之器，不得已而用之，恬澹为上。 胜而不美，而美之者，是乐杀人。 夫乐杀人者，不可得志於天下。 林氏曰：君子居每以左为贵，而兵则尚右，便是古人亦以兵为不祥之事，非君子之所乐用，必不得已而后为之，不幸而用兵，又以恬淡为上。 恬淡无味也，即是不得已之意也。 虽胜亦不为喜。 不美者，言用兵不是好事也。 若以用兵为喜，则是以杀人为乐，岂能得志於天下，《孟子》曰：不嗜杀人者能一之，亦是此意。 ○吕氏曰：天地之道左阳而右阴，阳主德主生主柔弱，平居则贵之，阴主刑主杀主刚强，用兵则尚之。 ○吴氏曰：恬者不欢愉，淡者不浓厚，为上不喜好用兵，乃为上也。 胜而不美，谓兵虽得胜，亦不肯以为美事。 若以战胜为美事，则是以杀人为乐也。 不可得志於天下，要终而言之，以示戒也。 吉事尚左，凶事尚右。 偏将军处左，上将军处右，言以丧礼处之。 杀人众多，以悲哀泣之，战胜以丧礼处之。 林氏曰：偏将军之职位，本在上将军之下，今上将军居右而偏将军居左，是古人以兵为凶事，故以丧礼处之。 左阳右阴也，丧礼则尚阴，幸而战胜，亦当以居丧之礼，泣死者而悲哀之可也。 此章之意，盖言人之处世，有心求胜者，皆为凶而不为吉也。 ○何氏曰：战胜如不胜，以丧礼处之，慈之至也。 秦师败於崤而归，秦伯素服郊次，向师而哭，此战败则宜之，未有战胜反为之哀者，自非深体天地好生而兼爱民物者，畴能动心及此。 慈故能勇，哀故能胜，有道存焉，若乃以兵为佳，以杀为乐，以胜为美，是不知道，是不知天。 第三十二章 道常无名，朴虽小，天下不敢臣。 侯王若能守，万物将自宾。 吕氏曰：夫道之难言，包罗万有，贯穿毫芒，岂得而名喻之以朴。 且朴者真精纯素，一而不杂，洋洋乎大哉，无乎不在。 小者非小大之谓，以其无方无体，无为无形，微妙之极也，搏摸拟议，莫得仿髴，故名之以小。 夫世之材器，既有名则为无名所役矣，惟道之朴也，万物之所系，天地不能犯，圣智不能干，而天下岂能臣之乎。 为侯为王，能守其朴，则天下罔不治矣。 喻之於己，侯王者本来赤子，无相天君谓之元神，守而勿失，与神为一。
chunks.translated_text:
With the Dao to govern the people and the state, how could one not take the use of arms as a warning and skillfully employ their consequences?

**Master Dong** says:
When things reach their peak of strength, they grow old; when arms are at their strongest, they meet defeat. Thus, those who rely on military might cannot fully preserve their virtue in victory. To employ strength is precisely what hastens decay and decline—all of which are contrary to the Dao. One should know when to stop early.

**Chapter Thirty-One**
Fine arms are instruments of ill omen. People detest them, and thus those who follow the Dao do not wield them.

**Master Lin** says:
Fine arms mean delighting in warfare, taking pleasure in using arms—this is the nature of an ill-omened person. An ill-omened person engaging in ill-omened deeds makes arms an ill-omened instrument, which the world detests. Hence, those who follow the Dao do not use them.

**Master Li** says:
Not using arms to subdue the world, those who rank arms as ill-omened instruments—this is the Sage’s profound warning to all future rulers of states. With non-action, purity, and tranquil governance, the realm naturally attains peace. Though arms exist, they are not displayed, and the scourge of contention is forever averted.

**Master Lü** says:
Arms are not tools for achieving great peace and governance. Though they may be used to punish tyranny, if one is forced to employ them, how can one avoid dark machinations? Those who adorn themselves with weapons as ornaments are already indulging in their cruelest use. This is to glorify a deadly instrument and hope for the world’s blessing—it is not only hated by people but also feared by all things.

The *Continuation of the Comprehensive Mirror to Aid in Government* records that Song Emperor Taizong said to his close ministers:
*"When I read in Laozi that ‘Fine arms are instruments of ill omen,’ and that the Sage uses them only when unavoidable, I have never failed to reflect on this as a solemn warning three times over.*

*The virtuous in repose honor the left; in war, they honor the right.*

*Arms are instruments of ill omen, not the tools of the virtuous. Used only when unavoidable, tranquility is supreme.*

*To win yet not take pride in it, yet to take pride is to delight in killing. Those who delight in killing cannot fulfill their ambitions in the world.*

**Master Lin** says:
The virtuous always honor the left in repose, yet in war, they honor the right—this shows that even the ancients regarded arms as ill-omened deeds, not something the virtuous would willingly use. They are employed only when unavoidable. Even if forced to wage war, they hold tranquility in highest regard. Tranquility is without relish, signifying the unwillingness born of necessity. Though victorious, they do not rejoice. ‘Not taking pride’ means war is no good deed. If one takes pride in war, then killing becomes a delight—how could such a person ever fulfill their ambitions in the world? As *Mencius* says: ‘Those who do not delight in killing can unite the world.’ This is the same meaning.

**Master Lü** says:
The Dao of Heaven and Earth places yang on the left and yin on the right. Yang embodies virtue, life, and gentleness—thus, in repose, it is honored. Yin embodies punishment, killing, and strength—thus, in war, it is exalted.

**Master Wu** says:
Tranquility means without exultation; simplicity means without excess. To hold war in disdain is to govern supremely. Though victorious, they do not glory in it—war is no noble deed. If one glories in victory, then killing is their delight. Those who delight in killing cannot fulfill their ambitions in the world. This is the final admonition.

*Auspicious rites honor the left; inauspicious rites honor the right. The Assistant General stands to the left, the Commanding General to the right—this is to treat war as a funeral.*

*When many die, one mourns with tears. Victory in war is treated as a funeral.*

**Master Lin** says:
The Assistant General’s rank is subordinate to the Commanding General, yet here the Commanding General stands to the right while the Assistant General stands to the left—this shows the ancients treated war as an inauspicious affair, thus observing funeral rites. Left is yang, right is yin; funeral rites exalt yin. Even if victorious, one should treat it as mourning, weeping for the dead with sorrow. The intent of this chapter is that those who seek victory in life are doomed to misfortune, not blessed.

**Master He** says:
To treat victory as though it were defeat, observing funeral rites—this is the height of compassion. When the Qin army was defeated at Heng and retreated, the Duke of Qin wore mourning attire at the outskirts and wept toward the troops. This was fitting for defeat, but there has never been one who, upon victory, mourned in this way. Only those who deeply embody Heaven and Earth’s love for life and universal compassion could be moved to such grief.

Compassion makes one courageous; sorrow makes one victorious. The Dao resides here. But if one takes arms as fine, killing as delight, and victory as beautiful, then one does not know the Dao, one does not know Heaven.

**Chapter Thirty-Two**
The Dao is ever nameless. Though crude and seemingly small, the world dares not submit to it. If lords and kings can preserve it, all things will come of their own accord.

**Master Lü** says:
The Dao is difficult to speak of—it encompasses all things, penetrating the finest and the vast. How could it be named or compared to simplicity? Crude refers to its pure, unadulterated essence, one without mixture, boundless and all-pervading. Though called "small," it is not small in size, but in its formlessness, its non-action, its subtle and wondrous nature—beyond grasp or imitation. Thus, it is named "small."

All worldly tools and instruments, once named, are subject to the nameless. Only the Dao’s crudeness underpins all things—Heaven and Earth cannot violate it, sages and wise cannot interfere, and yet how could the world submit to it? If lords and kings preserve this crudeness, the world will naturally be governed.

To liken it to oneself: lords and kings are originally like unspoiled children. The unmanifest Heavenly Sovereign is called the Original Spirit. If one guards it without loss, one becomes one with the Spirit.

**Master He** says:
Why does the Sage retreat in humility, unwilling to seek victory over the world? Because He sees that when the sun reaches its zenith, it declines; when the moon is full, it wanes; when things reach their peak, decline follows. Is this not the natural course of the Dao? If one knows this is not the Dao, then one must swiftly return to it, swiftly abandon what is not the Dao. The causes of ruined states are many, but those who delight in arms are doomed to fall.

chunks.original_text: 一之泰定，万气朝之，故曰道常无名，朴虽小，天下不敢臣，侯王若能守，万物将自宾。 ○何氏曰：道常二字句绝，如天常真常等字，即常道也。 大道无形无名，强名曰道。 无名乃道之常也，朴也。 凡可名可道者非真常也，器也。 故曰天地与人物，本皆道之原，俱出於太素，虚无之始端。 朴，太素也，无名之始也。 未判为万有之众体，惟包於大混之一。 朴微乎芒乎，难知难见，故曰小也。 圣人决本常根，见素抱朴，旨约而易操，事少而功多，中心无为，以守至正，道虚而实，无而有，以之居重御轻，可以君天下，而天下何敢臣之。 以之处静制动，可以为万物主，而万物将自宾之。 ○李氏曰：道常无名者，虚无自然也，朴虽小，至微也，天下不敢臣，至尊也，万物将自宾，无不服也。 ○林氏曰：道常无名，即可名非常名，无名之朴，道也，虽若至小，而天下莫不尊之，孰敢卑之，故曰不敢臣。 为王侯者，若能守此道，则万物自宾服之矣。 天地相合，以降甘露，人莫之令而自均。 吕氏曰：天地交而万物生，人道交而功勋成，况圣人作而万物睹，和气默应，上际于天，下蟠於地，甘露降，嘉禾生，品汇根荄，咸被其泽，道参天地，德合神明，民不待命令而自然胥悦，此皆皇国符瑞之兆，非使然而然。 扣之己焉，坎离交而二炁合，上及太清，下及太宁，化为甘露，润泽一切，初莫知令，升降均平，出入玄牝，会于黄庭，洞达斯旨，立反婴儿。 ○何氏曰：圣人与天地合德，则时雨降，醴泉出，甘露可致也，与亿兆同心，则教化美，风俗移，天下不待令而自均也。 甘露者，王者之瑞应也，灵液如脂，美味如饴，松竹可受之。 以圣人之朴，静漠恬澹，故自然之应如此。 ○李氏曰：天地相合者，惟德是辅也，以降甘露者，和气所致也。 自均者，自然和平也。 始制有名，名亦既有，夫亦将知止，知止所以不殆。 吕氏曰：时逐岁行，物因事显，散朴为器，因器制名，名分既立，尊卑是陈，不可越于上下，若不知止，徇名忘朴，弃本逐末，则失其根本矣。 其知止者，既明且哲，自足於内，无求於外，岂有危殆乎。 ○林氏曰：道之始本无名，万物既作而后有道之名，制作也是朴散而为器也。 此名既有则一生二，二生三，何所穷已。 知道之士，当於此而知止，知止则不危殆矣。 ○何氏曰：自无名而有名，自有始而为母，每於朴散为器之中，自有大制不割之妙，沿流溯源，傍本探末，复始相中，泯於无形，不使失道，远而忘返，则於止，知止何殆何辱，故曰有名则复於道。 功名长久，终身无咎此也，故曰不可得而名。 道之初可得而名，道之余知初者，合元始之道也，知余者契阴阳之枢，混之而为一，可与天地符。 ○吴氏曰：始者道也，制，制作也，犹言为也，有名者，德也。 道无名，自道而为德，则有名也，道之无名而为德，则名亦既有矣，故人之用此德者，当知止於德，不可再降而下也。 此章之意，若曰自无而适有，当知至於德而止，不可再适也。 德之有名以下，於道复下於德，可乎，知止於德，则犹未远於道也。 譬道之在天下，犹川谷之於江海。 吕氏曰：道者万物之所宗，川谷者水之所分，江海者水之所锺，而道之在天下，上则郁乎清都紫微，下则溷乎瓦甓稊稗，顺之则昌，逆之则亡，譬于海焉，善之则浸润万物，逆之则滂湃为沴，殊不知道愈下而愈高，海愈倾而愈有，圣人德兼天地，泽被迩遐，则民罔不归之。
chunks.translated_text:
The Dao’s supreme constancy is unassailable—all ten thousand *qi* bow to it. Hence it is said: **"The Dao is ever nameless."**

Though *pu* (crudeness) is small, the world does not dare to subject itself to it.
If lords and kings can preserve this *pu*, all things will naturally submit.

**○ Master He says:** The phrase *"Dao is ever"* is a complete sentence, like *"Heaven is ever true"* or *"constancy is ever true"*—it means the eternal Dao.

The Great Dao is formless and nameless; yet, when forced to name it, we call it "Dao."
Its namelessness is the Dao’s eternal essence—*pu* itself.
All things that can be named or spoken of are not true constancy, but mere instruments.
Thus, it is said: **"Heaven and Earth, along with all sentient beings, are originally rooted in the Dao, all emerging from the primordial *Tai Su* (Great Substance), the initial stage of emptiness and nothingness."**

*Pu* is the Great Substance, the origin of the nameless.
Before differentiation into the myriad forms of existence, it alone remains within the Great Chaos.
*Pu* is subtle beyond measure—hard to know, hard to see—thus it is called "small."

The Sage discerns the root of constancy and *pu*, embraces the Substance while preserving *pu*.
This is simplicity in essence and ease in practice, few actions yet great achievements,
a heart of non-action, safeguarding the utmost rectitude.
The Dao is both empty and real, void yet present—
with it, one governs the heavy and light,
and may rule the world,
yet how could the world dare to subject itself to such governance?

With it, one dwells in stillness yet commands motion,
and may become the master of all things—
yet all things will naturally submit to such mastery.

**○ Master Li says:** *"The Dao is ever nameless"*—this is the natural state of emptiness and nothingness.
*Pu* is small, yet supremely subtle—
the world does not dare to subject itself to it, for it is the utmost reverence.
All things will naturally submit—none will resist.
**○ Master Lin says:** *"The Dao is ever nameless"*—
though it may be named as "extraordinary" or "nameless," the nameless *pu* is the Dao itself.
Though it seems the smallest, the world cannot but honor it—
who would dare to belittle it?
Thus, it is said: *"the world does not dare to subject itself to it."*

For those who become lords and kings,
if they can preserve this Dao,
then all things will naturally submit and serve them.

Heaven and Earth unite in harmony,
and sweet dew descends.
No one commands it,
yet all is balanced naturally.

**○ Master Lü says:** When Heaven and Earth interact, all things are born.
When human Dao interacts, achievements are fulfilled.
What then if the Sage acts,
and all things respond?
The harmonious *qi* silently aligns—
above, it reaches the Celestial Clarity (*Tai Qing*),
below, it coils around the Great Tranquility (*Tai Ning*).
It transforms into sweet dew,
nourishing all things.
Initially, none know who commands it,
yet it descends and ascends in perfect balance,
entering and exiting through the Mysterious Mother (*Xuan Mu*),
converging at the Yellow Court (*Huang Ting*).
Piercing this meaning,
one establishes the reversal of the infant.
**○ Master He says:** When the Sage aligns with Heaven and Earth in virtue,
timely rains descend and sweet springs flow—
the sweet dew may be attained.
When the Sage unites in heart with all beings,
teaching and transformation flourish,
customs shift—
the world does not await commands but naturally finds harmony.
Sweet dew is the auspicious response of kings—
refined as fat, sweet as honey,
received by pine and bamboo alike.
Because the Sage preserves *pu* in stillness and quietude,
the natural responses are thus.

**○ Master Li says:** When Heaven and Earth unite,
it is virtue alone that supports them,
and sweet dew descends from harmonious *qi*.
Their natural balance is the peace of harmony itself.

From the beginning, there was *pu* and the nameless.
Once names arise, one must know when to stop—
knowing when to stop ensures no peril.
**○ Master Lü says:** With seasons passing and years turning,
things manifest through their functions.
*Pu* differentiates into instruments,
names arise from these instruments.
Once distinctions are set,
rank and hierarchy appear—
one cannot transgress above or below.
If one does not know when to stop,
pursuing names while forgetting *pu*,
abandoning the root for the branches,
then one loses their foundation.

The wise who know when to stop
are both enlightened and sagely,
self-sufficient within,
requiring nothing from without—
how could they face danger or peril?

**○ Master Lin says:** The Dao’s origin is nameless.
Once the myriad things arise,
then the Dao’s name appears.
Creation itself is the scattering of *pu* into instruments.
This name having arisen,
one generates two, two generate three—
where does it end?

Those who know the Dao
must recognize this point and stop—
knowing when to stop ensures no peril.

**○ Master He says:** From the nameless to the named,
from the beginning to the mother—
within every scattering of *pu* into instruments,
there lies a supreme principle that cannot be severed.
Tracing the flow to its source,
exploring the root to its branches,
returning to the beginning while harmonizing,
erasing distinctions into formlessness,
preventing the loss of the Dao—
those who stray and forget return,
yet stopping is perilous, stopping is humiliation.
Thus, it is said: *"Once named, return to the Dao."*

Long-lasting achievements and virtue
bring lifelong freedom from blame—
thus, *"it cannot be named."*

The Dao’s initial stage may be named,
but those who know the Dao’s remainder
also grasp the Dao of the Primordial Beginning (*Yuan Shi*),
and those who know its remainder
align with the pivot of yin and yang—
mixing into one,
they may harmonize with Heaven and Earth.

**○ Master Wu says:** The "beginning" is the Dao,
"making" is creation—
just as one says "to do."
The "named" is virtue.
The Dao is nameless,
yet when it manifests as virtue,
then it is named.
The Dao’s nameless virtue becomes virtue—
once named, one must know when to stop at virtue,
and not descend further.
The intent of this passage is:
when one moves from nothingness to existence,
one must know to stop at virtue—
it cannot be furthered beyond this.

Below the named virtue,
one returns to the Dao and descends to virtue—
is this possible?
Knowing when to stop at virtue,
one is still not far from the Dao.

To liken the Dao in the world
to rivers and valleys compared to the sea.

**○ Master Lü says:** The Dao is the origin of all things,
rivers and valleys are the divisions of water,
the sea is the gathering of water.
Yet the Dao in the world—
above, it ascends to the Celestial Clarity (*Qing Du*) and Purple Micro (*Zi Wei*),
below, it mingles with the humble and the coarse.
Following it brings prosperity,
contradicting it brings ruin—
like the sea, it is compared to this.
If one does good,
it permeates and nourishes all things,
if one does evil,
it surges and brings calamity.
Yet the Dao grows ever higher the more it descends,
the sea grows ever fuller the more it is tilted.
The Sage’s virtue encompasses Heaven and Earth,
nourishment extends near and far—
then the people cannot but return to such virtue.

chunks.original_text: ○吴氏曰：上文言自无而有，此又言自有而无，当复於道也，盖道之在天下犹江海，德者犹汉谷之会归于江海。 ○何氏曰：道之在天下，如江海之纳百谷，江海非欲於水，而水自归之，人能返朴无为，非欲於道，道自归之，自然而非强然也。 圣人冥心无为之始，而脱累有名之后，其道历万世而不变，则谓之真常者宜哉。 ○林氏曰：川谷之水必归之江海而后止，天下万物必归之道而后止，故曰道之在天下，犹川谷之於江海。 第三十三章 知人者智，自知者明。
chunks.translated_text:
**○ Master Wu says:** The preceding text speaks of arising from Nonbeing to Being;
this now speaks of returning from Being to Nonbeing—
both must be understood in terms of the Dao.
For the Dao in the world is like the sea and rivers,
while virtue is like the tributaries converging into them.

**○ Master He says:** The Dao in the world
is like the sea receiving all rivers—
the sea does not desire the waters,
yet the waters naturally flow to it.
If one returns to simplicity and non-action,
the Dao is not sought,
yet it naturally comes—
effortless, not forced.
The Sage begins with silent stillness and non-action,
then transcends all entanglements of name and form.
His Dao endures through ten thousand ages without change—
truly, it is the Eternal Constant.

**○ Master Lin says:** The waters of rivers and valleys
must flow into the sea before they rest,
and all things under Heaven
must return to the Dao before they cease.
Thus it is said:

chunks.original_text: 胜人者有力，自胜者强。 吕氏曰：知人则求备於物，制命於外，未若自知无所知，自明无所明，可谓真自知，真自明。 务於外者，以力胜人，务於内者，以道自胜，若夫建国立号，揽权作威，以号令天下，臣服诸侯，此非以力而胜於人乎。 自胜者尊道德，行仁义，克己复礼，谦而自下，而人归之，故天下莫能胜，非强而何。 ○何氏曰：人之常情，明於知人，暗於知己，强於胜人，怯於胜己，故知人不过是非利害之间，而一念知非，灵光常现，自明之大也。 胜人不过刚柔勇怯之际，而一念胜邪，天下大勇，自强之大也。 比之务外不务内者远矣。 ○吴氏曰：智能知人，循外之智尔。 能自知则内能尽性也，故谓之明。 有力能胜人，恃外之力尔，能自胜则内能克己，故谓之强。 知足者富，强行有志。 不失其所者久。 死而不亡者寿。 吕氏曰：成人之业，继人之后，施之万民，不失其所，不忘其本，着於久远，使后世不能企及。 其於身也，守真抱一，不为物迁，未尝须臾离也，然后入乎真常之域，亘古不变，与道同体，故曰不失其所者久。 圣人之道，传诸万世，布在方策，后世尊之师之，其人虽亡，其政若存。 有道之士，以生为寄，以死为归，其生也识趣圆明，与道合真，其死也脱胎神化，如蝉蜕焉。 身虽死而真身不亡，寿与二仪齐其绵邈，故曰死而不亡者寿。 ○何氏曰：自知而明可矣，必也为知足之知，则富不在天下，其足为道足，为神足也，是谓知之。 至自强而胜可矣，必也为强行之强，则志可挫万物，其行者为勤行，为独行也，是谓强之。 至此二句知足强行，粘上句一知字，一强字，义可见矣。 久在不失其所，夫所者归宿之地，《易》曰：艮其止，止其所，谓止之能止者，由止得其所也。 万物庶事，各有其所，得其所则安，故久，失其所则悖，焉能久。 寿在死不在亡，死者一终之义，《列子》无所由而常生者道也，由生而生，故虽终而不亡常也，《庄子》千岁厌世，去而上仙，乘彼白云，至于帝乡是也。 如传云立德功言三不朽，亦其不亡者。 ○李氏曰：知足者贫亦乐，强行者终始不怠，固守者无危殆，内明者出生死，死而不亡者，真一长存也。 ○吴氏曰：老子之道，以昧为明，以弱为强，而此章言明言强何也，曰老子内非不明，外若昧尔，内非不强，外示弱尔。 其昧其弱，治外之药，其明其强，治内之方，并行而不相悖也。 ○董氏曰：所犹艮卦止其所之所，惟知道而能行，则自得其所而居安矣，故虽物变无穷，而心未尝失，乃无入而不自得，所以久也。 惟能自知自强，而不失其所，乃寿之实也，此即不随生死所变者，卓然而独存，是乌可以数量论哉。 第三十四章 大道泛兮，其可左右。 吕氏曰：至高无上，至深无下，莫测其涯泪，莫寻其根源，其唯道乎。 包藏宇宙而无表里，充塞太虚，动静不失，往来无穷，泛然无所系碍，游於万物，左之右之而无不可，其用大矣，至於一身，大道元气，弥漫百骸，在节满节，在关满关，泛然无乎不在。 ○柴氏曰：道者万物之奥，无往不在。 经中句法多是兮字联其字，如荒兮其未央哉，怕兮其未兆之句。 又十五章皆是兮字联其字，盖老子文法如此。

「Conquering others is strength,
but conquering oneself is power.
Master Lü says: Knowing others means seeking perfection in things,
controlling life through external means—
this is not as good as knowing oneself without knowing,
enlightening oneself without enlightenment,
which may truly be called **self-knowing** and **self-enlightenment**.
Those who strive externally conquer others with force,
but those who strive internally conquer themselves with the Dao.
To establish a state and proclaim a name,
to grasp authority and wield influence,
to command all under Heaven,
to subjugate the feudal lords—
is this not the use of force to conquer others?
The self-conqueror upholds **virtue/power** and **Dao**,
practices **ren** (benevolence) and **yi** (righteousness),
overcomes self to restore propriety,
humble and self-effacing—
yet people flock to him.
Thus, none under Heaven can conquer him;
what else could this be but **power**?

Master He says: By human nature,
one is clear in knowing others,
but dim in knowing oneself;
strong in conquering others,
but timid in conquering oneself.
So knowing others is merely discerning right and wrong,
advantage and harm—
yet a single moment of knowing wrong,
and the **spiritual radiance** (*lingguang*) ever shines forth,
this is the greatest **self-enlightenment**.
Conquering others is merely a matter of strength and weakness,
courage and cowardice—
yet a single moment of overcoming evil,
and this is the greatest courage under Heaven,
the greatest **self-power**.
How far removed this is from those who strive externally but neglect internally!

Master Wu says: Intelligence can know others,
but this is merely external knowledge.
To know oneself is to exhaust one’s nature internally,
thus called **enlightenment**.
To have strength and conquer others is to rely on external force,
but to conquer oneself is to internally overcome self,
thus called **power**.
The contented man is rich,
the resolute man acts with purpose.
The steadfast man endures long.
The man who dies yet does not perish is long-lived.

Master Lü says: The accomplished man’s work
endures after his death,
benefiting all people—
he does not lose his place,
nor forgets his roots,
his influence lasts far into the future,
so that later generations cannot emulate him.
In his body, he guards the **True One** (*Zhenyi*), embraces unity,
and is not swayed by external things,
never for an instant departing from it—
then he enters the realm of the **Eternal Constant** (*Zhenchang*),
enduring through all ages without change,
unified with the Dao,
thus it is said: *The steadfast man endures long.*
The Sage’s Dao is transmitted through ten thousand ages,
recorded in books and decrees,
later generations revere him as their teacher,
though his person may have passed,
his governance remains as if alive.
The man of the Dao regards life as a temporary dwelling,
and death as his final return—
in his life, he discerns the **tendencies** (*qù*) with clarity,
unified with the Dao in truth;
in his death, he sheds the mortal form and attains **spiritual transformation** (*shenhua*),
like a cicada casting its shell.
Though his body dies,
his true self does not perish—
his longevity matches the **Two Principles** (*Eryi*) in its boundless extent,
thus it is said: *The man who dies yet does not perish is long-lived.*

Master He says: **Self-enlightenment** through self-knowing is possible,
but one must also attain the **knowing of contentment** (*Zhizú*),
then wealth is not bound by the world—
his contentment is **Dao-contentment**, **spiritual-contentment**,
this is called **true knowing**.
To achieve **self-power** and conquer is possible,
but one must also attain **resolute action** (*Qiángxíng*),
then his purpose can overcome all things—
his actions are **diligent action**, **solitary action**,
this is called **true power**.
Thus, the two lines—**knowing of contentment** and **resolute action**—
are connected to the preceding lines on **knowing** and **power**,
and their meaning becomes clear.
**Longevity** lies in not losing one’s place—
the place is the destination of return,
as the *Yijing* says: *"The **stopping** (*Gèn*) Principle stops at its place,
and finds rest in its place"*—
it means that the power to stop is one who stops at its proper place.
All things and affairs have their proper place,
to find it is to be at ease,
thus **longevity**.
To lose it is to go astray;
how could it endure?
**Longevity** lies in death, not in perishing—
death is the meaning of finality,
as the *Liezi* says: *"The Dao is the source of eternal life,
from life comes life—
though it ends, it does not perish eternally."*
As the *Zhuangzi* says: *"A thousand years of life may weary one of the world,
and they depart to ascend as immortals,
riding the white clouds,
reaching the realm of the Emperor."*
This is also the case.
As the saying goes: *"Establish virtue, achieve great deeds, and attain the Three Unperishables"* (*Sān Bùxiǔ*),
this too is the **not-perishing**.

Master Li says: The **contented man** finds joy even in poverty,
the **resolute man** never falters in beginning or end,
the **steadfast man** faces no peril,
the **internally enlightened** transcends birth and death—
the man who dies yet does not perish,
his **True One** eternally abides.

Master Wu says: The Laozi’s Dao
uses **obscurity** (*mèi*) as **enlightenment** (*míng*),
and **weakness** (*ruò*) as **power** (*qiáng*),
yet this chapter speaks of **enlightenment** and **power**—why?
Because Laozi is not obscure internally,
though externally he seems so;
not weak internally,
though externally he appears so.
His **obscurity** and **weakness** are remedies for external affairs,
his **enlightenment** and **power** are prescriptions for internal cultivation—
both are practiced without contradiction.

Master Dong says: The **place** is as the **stopping** Principle’s place in the *Yijing*—
only he who understands the Dao and can act upon it
finds his own place and dwells securely,
thus though external things change without end,
his heart never strays—
this is the way of **no entry without self-possession** (*Wùrù ér bùzìdé*),
the means to **longevity**.
Only he who can truly **know himself** and **strengthen himself**
without losing his place
attains true **longevity**—
this is the **unmoved** and **solitary** that does not perish with the changes of life and death,
standing alone and enduring eternally—
how could it be measured by mere quantity?

**Chapter Thirty-Four**
The Great Dao flows unrestrained,
its movement knows no left or right.
Master Lü says: It is the most exalted, most profound—
its boundaries are unfathomable,
its roots are untraceable.
Only the Dao could be so.
It encompasses the universe without distinction,
fills the boundless void,
its motion and stillness are unceasing,
its coming and going endless,
flowing freely without obstruction,
wandering through all things,
moving left and right without restriction—
its application is vast indeed.
Within the body, the Great Dao is the **original qi** (*yuánqì*),
pervading all hundred bones,
in the joints when full,
in the passages when full—
flowing freely without exclusion,
present in every part.

Master Chai says: The Dao is the mystery of all things,
its presence is never absent.
The text often employs the *"fú"* (*兮*) particle paired with *"qí"* (*其*),
as in *"Huāng fú qí wèicháng"* ("Vast and boundless, its limits are without end")
and *"Pèi fú qí wèizhào"* ("Frail and subtle, its signs are not yet revealed").
Again, in Chapter Fifteen, all lines use *"fú"* paired with *"qí"*—
this is the style of Laozi’s text.

chunks.original_text: ○林氏曰：泛兮其可左右，无所系着也。 ○何氏曰：大哉圣人之道，发育万物，峻极于天，此言泛者，渊渊乎其若海，巍巍乎其终复始也。 左之左之，宜於左。 右之右之，宜於右。 经曰：执大象，天下往，言无往而不可也。 万物恃之以生而不辞，功成不名有。 吕氏曰：生化之力，本於自然而已，而道何尝施其巧，矜其能乎。 天地至大，犹恃赖焉，其於万物，往者资之，求者与之，六合虽大，未离其内，秋毫虽小，待之成形，岂辞劳哉。 卓然独立，生之而不违，成之而不有，弗居其功，是法道之体也。 ○何氏曰：物物倚之孕育，在在随之呈露，而圣人处之裕如也。 ○林氏曰：物物皆道之所生，何尝辞之，既生矣，何尝居之以为功。 衣被万物而不为主，常无欲，可名於小，万物归焉而不为主，可名於大。 吕氏曰：夫道复於至幽，显於至变，生之畜之，若无端纪，覆之育之，各遂其性，若赤子之昼赖其乳食，宵藉其襁褓，广其爱育之德，为而不恃，长而不宰，任其自然而常无所欲。 内观其妙而无物不入，群动莫窥其归往之迹，可名於小矣，故曰万物归而不为主。 常无欲，可名於小，道隐无名，无名也者，广乎其无不容，渊乎其不可测，未始有物，惟其无物，则万物归之而无不同，同之而不为主，可以大名之矣。 ○何氏曰：衣被者，覆露之义，《庄子》：圣人遭之而不违，过之而不守，调而应之，德也，偶而应之，道也，则不辞不有不主之意可见矣。 常无欲者，静也，圣人一於无为无欲者，则心本无心，敛之不盈一握，朴虽似小而万物归焉，不为主则物各付，物散之则弥六合，何其大也，固曰天地固有恒矣，日月固有明矣，禽兽固有群矣，林木固有立矣。 放德而行，循道而趋，已至矣，由是而观，神人无功，圣人无名，何心於主宰哉，故曰功盖天下而似不自己，化贷万物而民弗恃，有莫举名，使物自喜，立乎不测，而游於无有此也。 ○李氏曰：衣被万物而不为主，忘其所自也，万物归之而不为主，任运自然也。 是以圣人终不为大，故能成其大。 林氏曰：惟其能小，所以能大，圣人之所以不为大者，故能成其功也。 此即守其雌为天下溪之意。 ○何氏曰：圣人终不为大，而大以之成，始虽不明有，而终不可掩其名之大，其以是道欤。 ○吴氏曰：此章首言天地之道，结句乃言圣人，盖圣人与天地一也。 岁功成而万物归焉，道之至大也，而天地不居其功，而万物不知所主，是天地之道虽大，而不自以为大，圣人亦若此矣，是以能成其大也。 ○吕氏曰：域中有四大，而帝王居其一焉，圣人执谦以为柄，处损以自居，下於人而人高之，卑於人而人尊之，忘其穹窿之势，去其矜伐之容，则可以成其道之大全矣。 第三十五章 执大象，天下往。 往而不害，安平泰。 何氏曰：大道无象，故无象之象，其为象也大矣，夫道也大包天地，细入毫芒，不可得而名状，故曰大象，言执云者，谓持此以往，人能体无名无形之道，循自然常然之化，则理身理国，贯古贯今，何往而不通。 虽天下吾往矣，不惟往而不害，且安其性命之情，平中之福，泰然无复事，极其所往，天人和同之际也。 《庄子》：苟得其道，无自而不可。

「○ Master Lin says: Vast and boundless, its presence can be left or right,
without any attachment or obstruction.

○ Master He says: Great indeed is the Sage’s Dao,
nurturing all things, reaching its apex in Heaven.
When speaking of *"fú"* (泛), it is profound as the sea,
lofty yet ever returning to its beginning.

Left is left, fitting to the left.
Right is right, fitting to the right.
The text says: *"Hold the Great Symbol"* (*zhí dàxiàng*),
and all under Heaven will follow—
for there is nothing it cannot traverse.

All things depend on it for birth yet it does not decline,
its work accomplished yet it claims no ownership.

Master Lü says: The power of generation and transformation
originates from Nature alone—
yet the Dao never applies its artifices,
nor boasts of its abilities.
Though Heaven and Earth are vast beyond measure,
they still rely on it,
and to all who seek, it gives.
Though the Six Extremes are vast,
they do not depart from its embrace,
and though the autumn hair is minute,
it awaits its shaping.
Does it not labor endlessly?
Standing alone, it gives life without resistance,
fulfills without possession,
does not dwell on its deeds—
this is the very essence of the Dao.

○ Master He says: All things lean upon it for gestation,
revealing themselves in every place,
while the Sage abides in ease.

○ Master Lin says: All things are born from the Dao,
how could it refuse them?
Once born, how could it claim them as its own?
Clothing and covering all things yet not ruling them,
ever without desire,
this may be called *"small"*—
all things return to it yet it does not rule them,
this may be called *"great"*.

Master Lü says: The Dao returns in the most hidden depths,
manifests in the most transformative ways.
It nurtures and shelters,
as if without beginning or end.
It covers and fosters,
each following its own nature—
like a babe by day relying on its milk,
by night on its swaddling.
Expanding its virtue of love and nurturing,
it acts yet does not rely,
it grows yet does not govern,
letting all unfold naturally and ever without desire.

Within, it observes its mystery,
and nothing escapes its embrace.
All movement cannot fathom its path of return—
this may be called *"small"*, hence it says,
*"all things return yet it does not rule"*.

Ever without desire,
this may be called *"small"*—
the Dao is nameless and hidden,
and its namelessness is vast beyond measure,
profound beyond reckoning.
Before anything existed,
it was without form—
then all things returned to it,
and there was no distinction.
It harmonized without ruling,
thus its greatness may be named.

○ Master He says: *"Clothing and covering"* means to shelter and reveal.
From the *Zhuangzi*:
The Sage encounters it without resistance,
passes through without clinging,
adapts and responds—this is *virtue*,
matches and aligns—this is the *Dao*—
and the meaning of *"not refusing, not possessing, not ruling"* is clear.

Ever without desire is stillness—
the Sage unifies in *non-action* and *non-desire*,
so its heart is without heart.
Gathered, it does not fill a palm’s grasp,
though simplicity may seem small,
all things return to it.
Not ruling means each thing is entrusted to its own way,
scattered yet filling the Six Extremes—
how vast it is!
Thus it is said:
Heaven and Earth have their constancy,
the sun and moon their brightness,
birds and beasts their groupings,
trees and woods their standing.

The Sage lets virtue flow and follows the Dao,
already attaining perfection.
From this perspective,
the Divine Person has no deeds,
the Sage no name—
why would it dwell on dominion?
Thus it says:
*"Its deeds cover all under Heaven yet seem not its own,
transforming and granting yet the people do not rely on it—
though it has no name to be raised,
it lets things rejoice in their own accord,
standing in the unfathomable,
wandering in the nonexistent."*

Master Li says: *"Clothing and covering all things yet not ruling"* means
forgetting its own origin.
*"All things return yet it does not rule"* means
letting all unfold naturally.

Thus the Sage never claims to be great,
and so it achieves greatness.

Master Lin says: Only by being small can one be great—
the Sage’s refusal to claim greatness
is how its deeds are fulfilled.

This is the meaning of *"retaining the feminine,
the Dao becomes the valley of all under Heaven."*

○ Master He says: The Sage never claims to be great,
yet greatness is achieved through this.
Though at first it may seem unclear and unpossessed,
its greatness cannot be concealed in the end—
is this not the Dao?

○ Master Wu says: This chapter begins with the Dao of Heaven and Earth,
then concludes with the Sage—
for the Sage and Heaven and Earth are one.

When the yearly work is complete and all things return,
this is the Dao’s ultimate greatness—
yet Heaven and Earth do not dwell on their deeds,
and all things know no ruler.
Thus, though the Dao of Heaven and Earth is great,
it does not claim greatness itself,
and the Sage is likewise—
hence it achieves greatness.

Master Lü says: Within the realm, there are four great things,
yet the Emperor resides in one of them.
The Sage holds humility as its instrument,
dwells in self-effacement,
is lowly so that others exalt it,
is humble so that others honor it.
It forgets its towering might,
discards its boastful demeanor—
then it can fulfill the Dao’s complete greatness.

**Chapter Thirty-Five**
*Hold the Great Symbol*, and all under Heaven will follow.
Go forth without harm,
and peace and tranquility endure.

○ Master He says: The Great Dao has no form,
so it lacks even the symbol of form—
yet its symbol is vast.
The Dao encompasses Heaven and Earth,
enters the minutest hairs—
it cannot be named or described,
thus it is called the *Great Symbol*.
To say *"hold"* means to uphold this and go forth—
if one can embody the nameless, formless Dao,
and follow Nature’s constant transformations,
then governing the body and the realm,
spanning past and future—
what path cannot it traverse?

Though I say *"all under Heaven is my path"*,
it is not merely that it does not harm—
it also calms the nature of life and death,
secures the blessings of moderation,
and stands serene without further action,
reaching the pinnacle of its journey—
the moment of perfect harmony between Heaven and humanity.

From the *Zhuangzi*:
*"If one attains its Dao,
there is nothing it cannot do."*

chunks.original_text: ○林氏曰：大象者，无象之象也，天下往者，执道而往行，之天下也，以道而行，则天下孰得而害之，天下无所害则安矣平矣泰矣。 ○政和注：安则无危，平则无陂，泰则通治。 乐与饵，过客止。 道之出口，淡乎其无味，视之不足见，听之不足闻，用之不可既。 何氏曰：五音六律足於耳，八珍九鼎足於口，此举其声味之切於人者言之，仅可为过客口耳一时之娱，而非所以怡神养寿之源也。 席罢客散，於我何有，凡物欲之足以撄人心者，皆此类也。 大道则不然，静以修身，声色有所不乐，俭以养生，滋味有所不嗜，游心於淡，合炁於漠，养其无象，象固长存，守其无体，体固全真，味无味而甘，视无视而明，闻无闻而聪，用无用而大。 用之不可既，夫既者尽也，非用之无尽，乃道之本不可尽也。 ○李氏曰：乐与饵，声味俱美，丧其无象，安能久乎。 道之出口，无味无象，无声无色，以其无体，故应用无尽。 ○林氏曰：乐，钟鼓之乐也，饵，饮食也，张乐设馔，以待嘉客，乐终食尽，客过则止矣。 过者去也，道之可味，虽若至淡，视之虽不可见，听之虽不可闻，言其不足悦耳目也，而用之於今古而不尽，此即物有尽而道无穷之意。 道之出口，言道形於言也，犹曰道之为言也。 第三十六章 将欲歙之，必固张之。 将欲弱之，必固强之。 将欲废之，必固兴之。 将欲夺之，必固与之。 是谓微明。 李氏曰：执大象，则能见事之机微，才见固张，便知将歙，未萌先兆，未举先知，非天下之微明，其孰能及此。 ○林氏曰：此八句皆是譬喻，只是得便宜处失便宜之意。 歙，敛也，弛也，张者必弛，强者必弱，兴者必废，得必有失。 与，得也，夺，失也。 人惟不知，自以为喜，而不知此理，虽晦而实明，故曰微明。 微犹晦也，言虽微而甚易见也。 ○何氏曰：天不可信，理无常是，谁能一之，日之将暝也大明，天之夺鉴者益疾，气有歙张，势有强弱，数有废兴，物有与夺，是事之不可常者，此理之自然，非有欲不欲也。 经曰：飘风不终朝，骤雨不终日，天地尚不能久，而况人乎，是故以气言，阳极阴生，非欲歙而先张乎，以势言，物壮则老，非欲弱而先强乎，以数言，盛者必衰，非欲废而先兴乎，以物言，所贵能贱，非欲夺而先与乎。 将欲如此，必先如彼，借人事以明天理，不过盈虚消息之自然耳，天何容心哉，圣人何容心哉，后世不知此道，遂认为权谋操纵之用，此乃有机事，必有机心，去圣远矣。 此章大义，岂可以有心有为观之哉。 《庄子》：目将眇者，先观秋毫，耳将聩者，先闻蚋飞，体将僵者，先亟奔佚，心将迷者，先识是非，故物不至者则不及。 注者以为穷上及下，自然之数，圣人居中履和，终身全具。 是道也微乎深哉，难乎其明哉。 ○刘氏曰：张则必歙，强则必弱，兴则必废，与则必夺，物理之自然也，是谓微明，微明谓精微明着，昭然可考。 或以权术解其义，天之道利而不害，若是乎。 ○董氏曰：消息盈虚，相因之理，其机虽甚微隐，而理明着，惟清静柔弱自处者，不入其机。 柔之胜刚，弱之胜强。 鱼不可脱於渊，国之利器，不可以示人。 李氏曰：学道之士，存其无象，守其至柔，与物无竞，则自然知几。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Lin** says: *"The Great Symbol*—
this is the symbol of the formless.
To traverse all under Heaven*—
it is to hold the Dao and act accordingly.
When one governs all under Heaven with the Dao,
who can harm it? If all under Heaven is unharmed,
then it is tranquil, serene, and boundless.*

The **Zhenghe** annotation reads:
*"Tranquility means no peril,
serenity means no obstruction,
boundlessness means universal harmony."*

Music and feasts—
passing guests pause.
The Dao when spoken of,
is bland and without flavor;
when seen, it is not visible;
when heard, it is not audible;
when used, it cannot be exhausted.

The **He** says: *"Five tones and six pitches suffice the ears,
eight delicacies and nine tripods suffice the mouth—
these are but the most appealing sounds and tastes to mortals,
only enough to amuse passing guests for a fleeting moment,
not the true source of nourishing the spirit or prolonging life."*

When the feast ends and guests depart,
what concern are they to me?
All things that satisfy desire enough to unsettle the heart
are of this kind.

Yet the Great Dao is not so.
With stillness, one refines the self—
music and color have their limits in delight.
With frugality, one sustains life—
richness and taste have their limits in indulgence.
One wanders the heart toward the bland,
and unites the *qi* with the boundless.
Nurturing the formless, the form abides;
guarding the bodiless, the body remains whole.
Flavor without flavor is sweet,
vision without sight is clear,
hearing without sound is acute,
use without end is vast.

It cannot be exhausted—
for exhaustion means completion.
Not that its use is without end,
but that its Dao is inherently boundless.

The **Li** says:
*"Music and feasts—
sounds and tastes both exquisite—
if one abandons the formless,
how long can they endure?"*

The Dao when spoken of,
has no flavor, no form,
no sound, no color—
because it is bodiless,
its application is boundless.

The **Lin** says:
*"Music*—
the joy of bells and drums—
*feasts*—
the abundance of food and drink—
set music and prepare banquets
to welcome honored guests.
When the music ends and the feast is consumed,
the guests depart and it ceases.
Departure*—
this is leaving.
Though the Dao’s flavor may seem most subtle,
though it is unseen when viewed,
though it is inaudible when heard—
this is to say it does not please the ears and eyes—
yet its use spans past and present without end.
This is the meaning: things have limits,
but the Dao is boundless."*

When one speaks of the Dao emerging from words,
it is as if to say:
*"The Dao in its expression."*

**Chapter Thirty-Six:**
*"When one would contract it,
must first fully expand it.
When one would weaken it,
must first fully strengthen it.
When one would discard it,
must first fully promote it.
When one would take from it,
must first fully give to it.
This is called *subtle clarity*."*

The **Li** says:
*"To hold the Great Symbol,
one can perceive the subtlest workings of things—
once expansion is seen,
one knows contraction is coming.
Before the first sign appears,
one already knows.
This is not the *subtle clarity* of all under Heaven—
who else can attain this?"*

The **Lin** says:
*"These eight lines are all metaphors,
expressing only the principle:
where there is gain, there must be loss.
Contract*—
to gather and to slacken—
what is expanded must slacken;
what is strong must weaken;
what is promoted must decline.
Gain must have its loss.
To give*—
to receive;
to take*—
to lose.
Only those who do not understand
take this as joy,
unaware of the principle—
though it seems obscure,
it is truly clear.
Hence, it is called *subtle clarity*.
Subtle*—
as obscure as the dim—
yet its meaning is most evident."*

The **He** says:
*"Heaven cannot be trusted,
principles have no fixed state—
who can unify them?
The sun at its setting is most luminous,
yet Heaven in its withdrawal of light is swift.
*Qi* has its contraction and expansion,
forces have their strength and decline,
cycles have their rise and fall,
things have their giving and taking—
this is the nature of affairs,
not a matter of desire or aversion.
The Classic says:
*'Gusts of wind do not last the morning,
sudden rains do not last the day—
even Heaven and Earth cannot endure long,
how much more so mortals?*
Thus, speaking of *qi*,
when the yang reaches its peak,
the yin arises—
is it not that contraction follows expansion?
Speaking of force,
when things are at their height,
they age—
is it not that decline follows strength?
Speaking of cycles,
when things flourish,
they must wither—
is it not that fall follows rise?
Speaking of things,
what is precious must become base—
is it not that loss follows giving?
When one would act thus,
must first act otherwise—
borrowing human affairs to illustrate Heaven’s principles,
it is but the natural ebb and flow of fullness and emptiness.
Heaven has no partiality—
the Sage has no partiality.
Later generations unaware of this Dao
mistook it for schemes of manipulation,
yet this is but the interplay of circumstances,
where there is a mind for schemes,
the Sage is far removed.
How can this chapter’s grand meaning
be viewed through the lens of contrivance and action?"*

From the *Zhuangzi*:
*"When the eyes are about to fail,
first examine the autumn hairs;
when the ears are about to dull,
first hear the gnat’s flight;
when the body is about to stiffen,
first hasten to bound and leap;
when the heart is about to be confused,
first distinguish right and wrong—
thus, what does not come to pass
is not yet reached.*
The annotator takes this to mean:
*'The extremes of high and low,
the natural cycles—
the Sage abides in the middle,
walking the path of harmony,
fully whole throughout life.'*
This Dao is subtle yet profound,
difficult yet clear."*

The **Liu** says:
*"Expansion must lead to contraction,
strength must lead to weakness,
promotion must lead to decline,
giving must lead to taking—
this is the natural order of things,
called *subtle clarity*—
subtle clarity*—
the most refined and evident.
Some interpret this as a matter of strategy,
yet the Dao of Heaven is beneficent and does not harm—
such is its nature."*

The **Dong** says:
*"The ebb and flow of fullness and emptiness—
a principle of mutual dependence,
though its workings may be subtle and hidden,
its meaning is clear and evident.
Only those who dwell in purity, stillness, and weakness
do not fall into its schemes.
Softness overcomes hardness,
weakness overcomes strength.
Fish cannot be plucked from the depths,
and the state’s sharpest tools
should not be shown to the people."*

The **Li** says:
*"Those who study the Dao,
preserve the formless,
hold to the utmost softness,
compete with nothing—
then naturally know the omens."*

chunks.original_text: 苟用刚暴，尚权谋智术，求之胜物，非道也哉。 比如鱼乃水中物，求异群鱼，欲脱於渊，可乎？ 既不可，则人亦不可尚权，尚权者反常也，如鱼离渊必死。 国之利器，不可以示人，即孔子所谓可与立，不可与权同一义。 圣人用权，反常合道，尚不可轻为，而况常人乎，可不戒哉。 ○何氏曰：天下莫柔弱於道，道之所以柔弱者，包裹天地，贯穿万物，此言柔弱之胜刚强也，故曰人在道中，道在人中，鱼在水中，水在鱼中，道去人死，水乾鱼终，此言鱼以潜渊，人以道养，轻脱则必败矣。 利器者，开阖变通之权，如庖丁解牛，神行肯綮，善刀而藏，十九年刃若新发於硎，夫岂可以示人。 老氏曰：权者，圣人所以独见，《庄子》曾举此章鱼不脱於渊二句，而继之曰：圣人者，天下之利器也，非所以明天下也，神而用之，所以救世变於无穷，其不以示人，夫岂愚其民，虑患之意深矣。 ○吕氏曰：鱼在水，藏於深渊以自存，则孰能苦之，倘失於渊，则人得而取之，荡而失水，则蚁得而困之。 利器，权也，民或得而窥之，是犹持太阿而授以柄，轻用其国，国必危矣。 内取诸身，则鱼在水中，水在鱼中，人在气中，气在人中，鱼去水则死，人失气则亡，鱼能韬鳞掩藻，吐纳其水，则本不死，人能退栖福地，吐纳其气，则本不亡。 国之利器，道之天机也，若以轻泄於人，则天谴立至，《大洞天宪经》曰：非人传之谓之泄，天宝至哉，天机岂妄宣泄。 《南华经》云：夫有干越之剑，匣而藏之，不敢用也，保之至也，意盖以此。 ○河上公曰：利器，权道也，治国权者，不可以示执事之臣也。 治身道者，不可以示非其人。 ○林氏曰：渊喻道，鱼喻人也，人之不能外於道，犹鱼之不可脱於渊也。 第三十七章 道常无为而无不为，侯王若能守，万物将自化。 何氏曰：《庄子》：万物虽殊，理道不私，故无名，无名故无为，无为而无不为。 前章无名之上冠以道常二字，此章亦然，经曰：常无欲以观其妙，常有欲以观其缴，惟常无故无为，常有固无不为，其道一也。 此无为而无不为，所以为道之大常也。 道常句绝，是总标也，无为无不为，乃并言之，《庄子》：虚则实，实则伦，静则动，动则得，此所谓无为者，虚静自然之常道也。 圣人曷常沉空滞寂，而一无所为哉？ 尸居而龙见，渊默而雷声，神动而天随，从容无为，而万物炊累焉，其何故也。 无为而无不为，天地也，圣人以天地为本，故得性者，此真常也，应物者，亦此真常也。 动静无端，体用一源，盖无为者道之常也，而无不为者亦道之常也。 道无在而无不在，侯王能守此道，则道行於万物，不期化而自化也。 ○林氏曰：此章与道常无名章句皆同，无为而无不为，自然而然也，侯王若能守此无为之道，则不求化万物，而万物自化矣。 ○吕氏曰：身之所拟，应接无心，凝神太定，斯无为也。 侯王者泥九帝一，守而勿失，津化为液，液化为髓，髓化为精，精化为元珠，元珠化为金丹，此非万化之化而何。 化而欲作，吾将镇之以无名之朴。 无名之朴，亦将不欲。 不欲以静，天下将自正。 何氏曰：化虽上作下应，而欲作将作之机，圣人尤谨之。 神而化之，使民宜之，不先时而躁，不后时而缩，其机如此，圣人亦不认为己功，吾将由无为之化，还无名之朴。
chunks.translated_text:
「If one were to employ harshness and violence,
or to rely on stratagems and clever tactics,
and seek to triumph over all things—
this would not be the Dao/Way, indeed.

Just as fish are creatures of water,
if one seeks to differ from other fish
and desires to escape the depths—
is this possible?

Since it is not possible,
then humans too cannot rely on stratagems.
Those who rely on stratagems
go against the natural order—
like fish leaving the depths, they must perish.
The state’s sharpest tools
should not be shown to the people,
as Confucius said:
*"One may share the Dao/Way with them,
but not one’s stratagems."*
The same meaning applies here.

The Sage uses stratagems,
yet does so by reversing the natural order
to align with the Dao/Way—
still, this should not be done lightly.
How much more so for ordinary people—
should they not be warned?

The **He** says:
*"Under Heaven, nothing is softer and weaker than the Dao/Way.
The Dao/Way is soft and weak,
encompassing Heaven and Earth,
penetrating all things.
This is how softness and weakness
overcome hardness and strength.
Thus, when humans dwell in the Dao/Way,
the Dao/Way dwells in humans,
just as fish dwell in water,
and water dwells in fish.
The Dao/Way departs from humans, they die;
water dries from fish, they perish.
Fish that hide their scales and conceal their fins,
inhale and exhale the water,
do not die—
humans who retreat to blessed lands,
inhale and exhale the *qi*,
do not perish either.
The state’s sharpest tools
are the Dao/Way’s hidden principles—
if one were to reveal them lightly,
Heaven’s retribution would swiftly arrive.
The *Great Cave of Heaven Constitution Scripture* states:
*"To reveal what is not meant for humans is called ‘leakage’;
Heaven’s treasures are profound indeed—
its hidden principles should not be recklessly disclosed."
The *Southern Huaxia Scripture* says:
*"There are swords of Gou and Yue,
yet they are kept in their cases,
not dared to be used—
this is how they are preserved,
and the meaning is the same."*

The **River Above Master** says:
*"Sharp tools are stratagems of the Dao/Way.
When governing the state with stratagems,
one should not show them to officials.
When practicing the Dao/Way for oneself,
one should not reveal them to those unworthy."*

The **Lin** says:
*"The depths symbolize the Dao/Way,
and fish symbolize humans—
just as fish cannot escape the depths,
so humans cannot exist outside the Dao/Way."*

**Chapter Thirty-Seven** says:
*"The Dao/Way is ever without action,
yet nothing remains undone.
If lords and kings could uphold it,
all things would transform of their own accord."*

The **He** says:
*"In the *Zhuangzi*,
though all things differ,
their principles and Dao/Way are not exclusive—
thus, they are nameless.
Because they are nameless,
there is no action.
Yet without action, nothing remains undone.
The phrase ‘the Dao/Way is ever without action yet nothing remains undone’
is the great constant of the Dao/Way.

The ‘constant’ is without desire,
to observe its subtlety—
the ‘constant’ with desire,
to observe its transformations.
Only the constant without desire
is without action,
while the constant with desire
is without anything left undone—
yet the Dao/Way is one.

This ‘without action yet nothing remains undone’
is the Dao/Way’s true constant.
The Dao/Way is without presence yet without absence—
if lords and kings could uphold this Dao/Way,
it would manifest through all things,
not requiring transformation yet naturally transforming itself."*

The **Lin** says:
*"This chapter aligns with ‘the Dao/Way is ever without name’—
‘without action yet nothing remains undone’
is the natural unfolding of the Dao/Way.
If lords and kings could uphold this Dao/Way of non-action,
then without seeking to transform all things,
all things would transform themselves."*

The **Lü** says:
*"The body’s imitation,
responding without deliberation—
when the spirit is too fixed,
this is non-action.
Lords and kings,
entangled in the Nine Sovereigns’ ways,
if they uphold and do not lose them,
will refine their essence into fluid,
fluid into marrow,
marrow into essence,
essence into the primal pearl,
and the primal pearl into golden elixir—
what else could this be but the transformation of ten thousand things?
If one desires to act upon this transformation,
I shall restrain them with the nameless *purity*.
The nameless *purity* also desires not to act.
Without desire, there is stillness—
and under Heaven, all will naturally align."*

The **He** says:
*"Though transformation acts from above and responds below,
the mechanism of desire to act or to not act
is something the Sage holds most carefully.
The Sage transforms through divine means,
making people adapt to it—
not rushing ahead of its time,
nor lagging behind—
its mechanism is thus.
The Sage does not claim this as his own merit;
I shall follow the transformation of non-action,
returning to the nameless *purity*."*

chunks.original_text: 镇之云者，雕琢复朴，块然独以其形立之意，虽感而遂通之中，有寂然不动者，在夫所谓无名之朴。 道之始也，不可得而名也，圣人亦将不欲，而况朴散之器，非常之名乎。 言道尚无心，而况非道乎，如是则圣人之心静矣，一心定而万物服，天下其不正乎。 ○吴氏曰：欲谓有心为之，作犹起也，言未能纯乎无为之道者，方将待物之化，而遽有心於欲其化，欲之之心一起，则非无为之道矣。 镇谓压定，使之不起也。 无名之朴，谓无为之道也。 欲作之时，必将以此无名之朴镇其有心之欲，谓以道而自治也。 既以此无名之朴镇其欲，则其欲亦将不欲矣。 静者作之，反其始也，欲作既以道镇之，则欲者不欲，而作者静矣，故虽无心正天下，而天下将自正。 ○吕氏曰：其於己也，一念才动，则谓之情，情动则万化作矣，念既已漏，急须反照，灭其动心，还其纯素，镇之以朴，庶可一其性，故曰化而欲作，吾将镇之以无名之朴。 且夫道本无形，假朴以为言，圣人又恐滞迸之流，执其朴而为用，忧其弊之不救，以谓使天下之群实，心莫若虚，应天下之群动，心莫若静，惟窒欲以空其性，绝学以虚其心，以之修身，无自而不得，以之治性，无往而不可，如此则天下泰然将正而定矣。 ○李氏曰：天地无为，万物发生，圣人无为，万民安泰。 以修炼言之，都无作为，於安静之时，存其无象，毫发之动，便要先觉，既觉便以无名朴镇之，朴本无形，又曰无名，谓空也。 道德真经集义卷之五竟 道德真经集义卷之六
chunks.translated_text:
The saying *"to restrain"* means
to carve and return to the unadorned—
to stand alone, solid and unyielding in form,
though responsive yet still at its core.
This is what is called the nameless *purity*.

The Dao at its origin
cannot be named at all.
The Sage does not even desire it,
let alone the scattered vessels of *purity*,
which bear no extraordinary name.

If the Dao itself requires no intent,
how much more so that which is not the Dao?
Thus, the Sage’s mind is tranquil—
when the mind is unified and steadfast,
all things submit.
How could the world not align?

○ **Master Wu** says:
To speak of acting with intent is like stirring—
to say that one has not yet attained the purity of non-action,
and yet already waits for things to transform,
suddenly harboring intent toward their transformation—
the moment this intent arises,
it is no longer the Dao of non-action.

*"To restrain"* means to press down and settle,
preventing any disturbance.
The nameless *purity* refers to the Dao of non-action.
When the impulse to act arises,
one must restrain this intentional desire
with this nameless *purity*—
that is, to govern oneself through the Dao.
Once this nameless *purity* restrains the desire,
the desire itself will cease to desire.
The stillness that follows is the return to the origin—
when the desire to act is restrained by the Dao,
the desiring ceases,
and the one who acts becomes still.
Thus, though the Sage acts without intent,
the world will align of its own accord.

○ **Master Lü** says:
Within oneself, the moment a thought stirs,
it is called *emotion*—
when emotion moves, all transformations arise.
Once the thought has slipped through,
one must urgently reflect back,
extinguishing the restless mind,
restoring the pure simplicity,
and restraining it with *purity*—
only then may one unify the nature.
Hence it is said:
*"When transformation stirs to act,
I shall restrain it with the nameless purity."*

Moreover, the Dao is originally formless;
*purity* is but a borrowed term.
The Sage fears that even this may become rigid and fixed,
that clinging to *purity* for use
might lead to exhaustion beyond remedy.
Thus, he declares:
To let the world’s myriad forms be,
the mind must be empty;
to respond to the world’s myriad movements,
the mind must be still.
Only by suppressing desire to empty the nature,
and severing learning to empty the mind,
can one refine the self—
without obstruction, nothing is unattained;
can one govern the nature—
without exception, nothing is unachievable.
Thus, the world will naturally settle and align.

○ **Master Li** says:
Heaven and Earth act without doing,
and all things emerge.
The Sage acts without doing,
and all people thrive in peace.

Speaking of cultivation and refinement,
there is no deliberate action—
in moments of tranquility,
preserve the formless.
At the slightest movement,
one must first become aware,
and upon awareness,
restrain it with the nameless *purity*.
*Purity* is formless;
it is also called *nameless*—
meaning *emptiness*.

*(End of Volume Five of the Collected Commentaries on the Dao De Jing)*

The **He** says:
*"Though transformation acts from above and responds below,
the mechanism of desire to act or to not act
is something the Sage holds most carefully.
The Sage transforms through divine means,
making people adapt to it—
not rushing ahead of its time,
nor lagging behind—
its mechanism is thus.
The Sage does not claim this as his own merit;
I shall follow the transformation of non-action,
returning to the nameless *purity*."*

chunks.original_text: 盱江危大有集 第三十八章 上德不德，是以有德。 下德不失德，是以无德。 上德无为而无以为，下德为之而有以为。 上仁为之而无以为，上义为之而有以为，上礼为之而莫之应，则攘臂而扔之。 何氏曰《庄子》：古之人在混茫之中，与一世而澹漠焉，人虽有智，无所用之，此之谓至一，莫知为而常自然。 逮德下衰，及唐虞始为天下兴治之流，淳散朴，离道以善，险德以行，然后去性而从心。 心兴心识知，而不足以定天下，然后附之以文，益之以博，文灭质，博溺心，然后民始惑乱，无以反其性情，而复其初。 此章大旨，尽在是矣。 夫上德不德，则混茫澹漠也，不失德而无德，则为者败，执者失矣。 上德无为而无以为，则至一自然也。 下德为之而有以为，则所谓始为天下矣。 上仁为之而无以为，至仁无亲，去德犹未远。 上义为之而有以为，以义制事，则下仁已一等。 以仁义视道德，则所谓离道以善，险德以行也。 曰不德，曰无以为，皆无心，无所为而为之谓天。 曰不失德，曰有以为，皆有心，有所为而为之谓人。 上礼为之而莫之应，又下义一等，附之以文礼也，於忠信为薄，益之以博智也，於道为华，其去性初转远矣。 上礼者，盛礼也，施厚报宜厚，报不敌施，争由是起。 攘臂，引去貌，败礼之人也。 扔，引也，字从亻者非。 ○林氏曰：为之而莫之应者，强民而民不从之也。 扔，引也，民不从而强以手引，强掣拽之也。 只是形容强民之意，故曰攘臂而扔之。 ○李氏曰：上章云常无为，故次之以上德不德。 上德无为，故合道，下德有为不合道。 仁义犹近德，可为进道之阶。 礼者纯是作为，以礼齐物，转不齐，盖有为终有失也，执之不失，亦可渐入佳境。 自仁而反德，自德而反道，直造无为也。 ○淮海秦氏曰：道德者仁义礼之大全，而仁义礼者，道德之一以道为本，以仁义为用。 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。 夫礼者，忠信之薄，而乱之首也。 前识者，道之华，而愚之始也。 何氏曰：首乱始愚，极言礼智流弊所至耳，《庄子》历历举此失道而后德以下五句，而曰今也以为物也，欲复归根，不亦难乎，其易也，其惟大人乎。 虽则云然，抑且曰匿而不可不为者事也，远而不可不居者义也，亲而不可不广者仁也，节而不可不积者礼也，中而不可不高者德也，一而不可不易者道也，虽此数者有上下先后之序，而以圣人并用之，则何莫非道也。 昔有通玄者云：道也者妙万物而为言，总两仪而称德，得之上者为道，得之中者为仁义，得之凉者为礼智，凉而失之者非人也，此言最简而明也。 ○吕氏曰：夫道者德之体，德者道之用，仁义由出於中，为可尚也，至於礼则去性益远，华盛而实亏，从事乎繁文末节而不求其本，忠信日以衰薄，虽施於日用之间，外则灿然，而其中则无有也，顺之则治，违之则乱，间不容发，岂非乱之首乎。 故曰三皇之有道也，不知其道化为五帝之德，五帝之有德，不知其德化为三王之仁义，三王之有仁义，不知其仁义化为秦汉之战争，此之谓也。 且世人以智为凿，从事浮华，虽自以为见，而不知至愚自此而始也，故曰前识者道之华，而愚之始也。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Way** of supreme virtue is not virtue,
thus it has virtue.
The **Way** of inferior virtue does not abandon virtue,
thus it lacks virtue.
The **Way** of supreme virtue acts without action—
yet nothing fails to be accomplished.
The **Way** of inferior virtue acts with action—
yet nothing is accomplished.

The **Way** of supreme benevolence acts yet nothing is accomplished;
the **Way** of supreme righteousness acts yet nothing is accomplished.
The **Way** of supreme propriety acts yet none respond,
and so they roll up their sleeves and force it upon them.

○ **Master He** says:
The ancients dwelled in **mixed chaos**,
and with the world became **dull and tranquil**.
Though people may have wisdom,
they had no use for it—
this is called **ultimate unity**,
where none know to act yet all abides in **constant naturalness**.

When virtue declined,
at the time of **Tang and Yú**,
they began to establish laws for the world,
dissipating **purity** and scattering **simplicity**,
abandoning the **Dao** for the sake of goodness,
and making virtue perilous through conduct.
Then they discarded **nature** and followed the **heart**.

The **heart** gives rise to **heart-awareness** and **mind-knowing**,
yet it was insufficient to govern the world—
so they adorned it with **culture** and enriched it with **learning**.
When **culture** extinguishes **substance**,
and **learning** drowns the **heart**,
then the people began to be bewildered and disordered,
unable to return to their original **nature** and **emotions**.

This chapter’s essence lies entirely here.
Supreme virtue not being virtue—
that is **mixed chaos** and **dull tranquility**.
Inferior virtue not abandoning virtue yet lacking it—
then the doer is ruined, the grasp is lost.

Supreme virtue acting without action—
that is **ultimate unity** in **naturalness**.
Inferior virtue acting with action—
that is what is called “beginning to act for the world.”

Supreme benevolence acting yet nothing is accomplished—
**ultimate benevolence** has no favorites,
and its distance from virtue is still slight.

Supreme righteousness acting yet nothing is accomplished—
when righteousness governs actions,
then inferior benevolence is already one rank below.

If one views **virtue** and **righteousness** through the lens of **moral power**,
then this is what is meant by
“abandoning the **Dao** for goodness” and
“making virtue perilous through conduct.”

When it says “not virtue,” and “nothing is accomplished,”—
all are without **heart**,
acting without purpose is called **Heaven**.
When it says “not abandoning virtue,” and “nothing is accomplished,”—
all are with **heart**,
acting with purpose is called **human**.

Supreme propriety acting yet none respond—
this is already one rank below inferior righteousness,
adorned with **culture** and **rites**.
In **loyalty** and **trustworthiness**, it is too thin;
enriched with **learning**, it is too ornate.
Its distance from **nature** grows ever farther.

Supreme propriety—
that is **excessive rites**.
When rewards are lavish, the response must be lavish,
yet if the response does not match the reward,
then strife arises from it.
Rolling up the sleeves—
a gesture of forcibly pulling away—
is the mark of one who violates propriety.
“Force” (扔) is “pull,”
but the character is incorrect.

○ **Master Lin** says:
“Acting yet none respond”—
this is compelling the people yet they do not follow.
“Force” (扔) is “pull,”
when the people do not follow yet one forcibly drags them by hand.
It is a strong and violent pulling.
This merely describes the act of compelling the people,
hence it says: *“roll up the sleeves and force it upon them.”*

○ **Master Li** says:
The previous chapter spoke of **constant non-action**,
so next it speaks of *“the **Way** of supreme virtue is not virtue.”*
Supreme virtue is non-action,
thus it aligns with the **Dao**.
Inferior virtue is action and does not align with the **Dao**.
**Benevolence** and **righteousness** are still close to virtue,
and can serve as steps toward the **Dao**.
**Rites** are purely action;
when **rites** are used to harmonize all,
they instead fail to harmonize—
for all action must eventually falter.
If one holds to them without faltering,
they can gradually lead one to a better state.
From **benevolence** to return to **virtue**,
from **virtue** to return to the **Dao**,
directly reaching **non-action**.

○ **Master Qin of Huáihǎi** says:
**Virtue** and **power** are the fullness of **benevolence**, **righteousness**, **rites**, and **wisdom**,
while **benevolence**, **righteousness**, **rites**, and **wisdom** are but aspects of **virtue** and **power**,
with the **Dao** as their foundation,
and **benevolence** and **righteousness** as their application.
Thus, when the **Dao** is lost, **virtue** follows;
when **virtue** is lost, **benevolence** follows;
when **benevolence** is lost, **righteousness** follows;
when **righteousness** is lost, **rites** follow.

**Rites** are the thinnest of **loyalty** and **trustworthiness**,
and the origin of disorder.
**Preconceived knowing** is the ornate aspect of the **Dao**,
and the beginning of **folly**.
**Master He** says:
Disorder begins with folly—
this is the utmost of how **rites** and **wisdom** lead to ruin.
The *Zhuāngzi* clearly enumerates these five stages from *“when the **Dao** is lost, **virtue** follows”*,
and says: *“Now they make these things into objects of pursuit,
and to return to the root is not so easy.
How simple it is! How simple it is—
only the **Great Person** can do it.”*

Though it says *“so”*,
it also says: *“Hidden yet cannot fail to act—this is **rites**.
Distant yet cannot fail to dwell upon—this is **righteousness**.
Near yet cannot fail to broaden—this is **benevolence**.
Moderate yet cannot fail to accumulate—this is **rites**.
Central yet cannot fail to elevate—this is **virtue**.
One yet cannot fail to simplify—this is the **Dao**.*
Though these have a sequence of high and low, first and last,
when the Sage employs them all,
what is not the **Dao**?

Once there was a **Master of Mysterious Transformation** who said:
The **Dao** is the subtle essence of all things,
and when spoken of, it is called **virtue**—
the totality of the **Two Poles** (yin and yang).
To attain it at the highest is the **Dao**,
to attain it in the middle is **benevolence** and **righteousness**,
to attain it in the lower is **rites** and **wisdom**.
To attain it in the cold and lose it—
that is not **human**.
This statement is the most concise and clear.

○ **Master Lǚ** says:
The **Dao** is the **substance** of **virtue**,
and **virtue** is the **application** of the **Dao**.
**Benevolence** and **righteousness** arise from the **heart**,
and are worthy of praise.
But when it comes to **rites**,
they grow ever more distant from **nature**,
ornate yet lacking in substance.
To engage in elaborate **rites** and trivial details
without seeking their foundation—
**loyalty** and **trustworthiness** grow ever thinner,
though outwardly they may gleam.
To follow them brings order,
to oppose them brings chaos—
not even a hair’s breadth can intervene.
Is this not the origin of disorder?

Thus it is said:
When the **Three Sovereigns** had the **Dao**,
they did not know that the **Dao** transformed into the **virtue** of the **Five Emperors**.
When the **Five Emperors** had **virtue**,
they did not know that **virtue** transformed into the **benevolence** and **righteousness** of the **Three Kings**.
When the **Three Kings** had **benevolence** and **righteousness**,
they did not know that **benevolence** and **righteousness** transformed into the **wars** of **Qín-Hàn**.
This is what is meant.

Moreover, the common people take **wisdom** as a chisel,
pursuing superficial ornamentation.
Though they think themselves perceptive,
they do not realize that **ultimate folly** begins from here.
Hence it says:
*“Preconceived knowing* is the ornate aspect of the **Dao**,
and the beginning of **folly**.”*
